Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of fundamental rights. D. Sharma, for the petitioner.
March 16, 1964. The judgment of the Court was delivered by WANCHOO, J.-This petition under Art. 32 of the Cons

issues.text: whether the system prevailing in the State of Rajasthan for the purpose of promotion of head-constables to the post of Sub-Inspectors of Police is violative of Arts. 14 and 16(1) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: stitution challenges the system prevailing in the State of Rajasthan for the purpose of promotion of head-constables to the post of Sub-Inspectors of Police as violative of Arts. 14 and 16 1  of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the practice of promotion of head-constables to officiate as Sub-Inspector rangewise amounts to denial of equal opportunity before the law and is hit by Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: He contends that the whole police force being one, the practice of promotion of head-constables to officiate as Sub- Inspector rangewise amounts to denial of equal opportunity before the law and is hit by Arts. 14 and 16

issues.text: whether the practice of confining promotions and reversions rangewise while making inter-range transfers freely and frequently violates Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It is contended that the practice of confining promotions and reversions to officers serving at a particular point of time in one particular range  i.e. where the vacancy or the surplusage of posts actually occurred  and at the same time making inter-range transfers freely and frequently and as a matter of official routine is bound to produce serious inequalities in promotions and reversions and also very haphazard changes in seniority amongst the officers inter se. The practice according to the petitioner allowing free transfers produces results which are violative of the equal protection of law and of equal opportunity to public servants in the matter of employment and thus violates Arts. 14 and 16 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether Section 2 of the Police Act, 1861 requires promotions in the police force to be made on a state-wide basis without regard to ranges and districts

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under s. 2 of the Police Act, the entire police establishment under a State Government is for the purposes of the Act, deemed to be one police force,

issues.text: whether the rangewise promotion system can be struck down on the ground that it may be abused through transfers by the Inspector General of Police

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that the system is capable of abuse and it is possible for the Inspector General of Police to trans- fer some Sub-Inspectors from one range to another with a view to deprive head-constables of a particular range of their due promotion and also with a view to favour head- companystables of another range who might otherwise be junior on the basis of length of service. Now it is not and cannot be disputed on behalf of the petitioner that transfers from one district to another or from one range to another even in these ranks of the police force may have to be made in the exigencies of public service or for reasons peculiar to a particular officer nor has it been contended that such transfers can be in any way illegal under the provisions of the Police Act.

holdings.text: The rangewise promotion system from head-constables to Sub-Inspectors does not violate Articles 14 and 16(1) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under s. 2 of the Police Act, the entire police establishment under a State Government is for the purposes of the Act, deemed to be one police force,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three-tier promotion system justified by administrative efficiency, local knowledge for lower ranks, and rare transfers; balances occasional seniority disparities against public service needs.

holdings.text: Section 2 of the Police Act, 1861 does not require promotions to be made on a statewide basis and permits subdivision into ranges and districts for efficient administration.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that under s. 2 of the Police Act, the entire police establishment under a State Government is for the purposes of the Act, deemed to be one police force,

holdings.reasoning_summary: While s.2 deems the force as one, the Act contemplates organization into ranges under DIGs and districts under SPs as necessary for efficient functioning.

holdings.text: The three-tier promotion system (districtwise to head-constable, rangewise to Sub-Inspector, statewide to Inspector) is valid as it promotes administrative efficiency and local knowledge.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, the Act envisages the Organisation of police administration under the Inspector General of Police by cr

holdings.reasoning_summary: Local knowledge essential for constable, head-constable, SI roles dealing directly with public; wider area at range level retains advantage; supervisory roles above need less.

holdings.text: The promotion system cannot be struck down merely because it is capable of abuse through transfers by the Inspector General.

anchor.surface_text: It is however urged that the system is capable of abuse and it is possible for the Inspector General of Police to trans- fer some Sub-Inspectors from one range to another with a view to deprive head-constables of a particular range of their due promotion

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transfers permissible for exigencies; abuse if wholesale could be remedied individually, not by invalidating system.

holdings.text: There is no policy or practice of free and frequent inter-range transfers of Sub-Inspectors, so the system does not cause inequalities violating Articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the allegation made in the petition that inter-range transfers have been freely and frequently

holdings.reasoning_summary: State policy via 1955 Order restricts transfers of low-paid staff outside home district/division; no evidence supports petitioner's claim of routine 3-4 daily transfers.

holdings.text: The petition fails as there is no violation of Articles 14 and 16.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the petition fails and is hereby dismissed. In the circumstances we make no order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative findings on system validity, s.2 interpretation, lack of abuse evidence, and rare transfers uphold no discrimination or denial of equal opportunity.

anchor.surface_text: In this view of the matter, the petition fails and is hereby dismissed. In the circumstances we make no order as to costs.
